rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some thermal properties of carbon dioxide and of ice
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The subject matter of this thesis has been divided into two main sections, one on the Thermal Constants of Liquid and Solid Carbon Dioxide and the other on the Latent Heat of Fusion and Specific Heats of Ice. While the principle underlying the experimental method employed in each part is the same, namely, adiabatic calorimetry, the two general problems investigated can be presented more conveniently and clearly if separated. A third section has been introduced on new experimental technique that has been developed in connection with this research and which 1s applicable to certain general calorimetric problems where precision measurements are desired. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The English versions of the Bible, and the various linguistic influences which affected their language and style
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: As Sir WaIter Scott, when he drew near his end, sat by the window of his library looking down on his beloved Tweed, he expressed a wish to his son-in-law Lockhart that he should have something read to him. Lockhart asked him from what book it should be. "Need you ask?" said Sir Walter, "there is but one." That book was the Bible, and it was the Bible in the Authorized Version of James the First. We may apply the words with perfect fitness to the place which the Bible holds in the rich treasure-house of our English Literature. Of all the books that have been written in our noble English tongue, "there is but one." If we could imagine some strange convulsion of nature in which all other books, even from "King Shakespere himself" down to the latest volume, were lost, and if only a copy of the English Bible were preserved our race would not be without its literary as well as its spiritual food,--its daily bread sufficient not only for the day but for the production of a new literature as glorious as the old. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Lord Palmerstonâ€™s policy of opposition to the project and to the construction of the Suez Canal
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Evidences of an ancient canal were discovered by Napoleon during his Campaign in Egypt, and he, desiring to facilitate communication with the East for purposes of conquest, had a survey made by the French engineer Lapere. The report which was given to Napoleon, at the conclusion of the work, showed that there existed a difference between the levels of the two seas, the Mediterranean Sea being 30 ft below the level of the Red Sea. The work of digging a canal was never carried out for Napoleon returned to Europe after the disastrous end to his expedition and he was never able to turn his attention again to the question of conquest in the East, which would have made a canal through the Isthmus of Suez a work ofthe greatest importance to him. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Pamerston, Henry John Temple, Viscount, 1784-1865
Suez Canal (Egypt)
History

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Twelve years of the Westminster Review, 1824-1836
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Rise of the Great Political Reviews in England. The opening of the nineteenth century marked a new era in periodical literature. It marked the beinning of the great reviews. The function of the review was to "discuss works of literature, art and science, to consider national policy and public events, to enlighten its readers upon these subjects and to awardpraise or censure to authors and statesmen.lt did not publish original matter, but confined itself to commenting upon or criticising the works and doings of others". (1) [...] During the eighteenth century, most reviews were of very slight importance and were under the control or influence of the publishers, who used them to advertise their wares, for at that time book-selling and book-publishing were but parts of a single enterprise. The sole object of the spurious criticism in these reviews was to increase the prosperity of the publisher. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An introduction to the philosophy of religion
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is well known to the student of philosophy and religion that the literature on these subjects is already very large and worthy. Despite this fact each year brings forth more contributions to these studies. The reason, we believe, is clear and weighty, for the final word has not yet been said about either of these problems. We live in an age that is investigating in a remoter past than was revealed to the students of the last generation. More intensive searching in regions that have already given forth truth has yielded rewardsof more and sometimes better truth. truth. Finally, it has become clear that if statements and decisions about the manner of living of earlier peoples are to be made, as well as about those who are contemporary with us, and they are to come at all near the truth, certain fundamental facts must be borne in mind. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The geology of a section of the Wunnummin Lake area
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The area of 150,000 sq. miles whioh forms the north western part of the Provinoe of Ontario 1s known as the Distriot of Patricia. The southern boundary of this district is the Albany - one of the large rivers whioh flow into James Bay. To the west lies the Provinoe of Manitoba, while the shore line of Hudson and James' Bay marks the borders of the district on the north and east. The drainage of the area is effected almost entirely by rivers that flow toward the north and east. A line drawn from the Albany diagonally northwestward would cross the headwaters of the largest three of these rivers, namely those of the Attawapiskat, the Winiek, and the Severn. In its upper courses the W1n1sk passes through three large bodies of water. The most westerly of these bodies is called Wunnummin Lake. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology & Mineralogy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The poetry of William Butler Yeats
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: William Butler Yeats was born at Sandymount, Dublin, on the 13th of June, 18'65. He was the eldest son of Jaok B. Yeats, R.H.A., the well-known artist, and the grandson of William Butler Yeats, M.A., Rector of Tullylish, County Down. On his mother's side he was descended from respectable merchants and ship-owners, his maternal grandfather, Willlam Pollexfen, having some little reputation in Sligo and the surrounding counties as a bold seaman and a shrewd business man. The ink of commerce did not, however, flow in the veins of all the Pollaxfens: George, the uncle of Mr. Yeats, having been secured an adequate income by the acumen and industry of his father, devoted himself in youth to the pleasures of the stable and hunting field, and in middle age to the more intelleotual delights of astrology and the practice of magic. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: English

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Assisted immigration and land settlement with special reference to Western Canada
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Colonization, as we know it today, is of oomparatively recent origin. It is unlike the pre-historic migrations of the Indo-European races, or the scarcely less distant expatriation of the Phoeniclans, or, again, the descent of the barbarous hill tribes upon the declining Roman Empire; nor were the offshoots of Rome or Greece true colonies. With them, they were little else than trading stations or military settlements. This factory system, also characterized the chain of outposts, which Portugal established from Madeira to Japan when she was at her zenith. With the fall of Portugal in 1580, the system itself did not collapse. The Dutch, and later, the French and English carried it on in the same territories. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics

rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Canada in the League of Nations
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: "The League of Nations" writes Vicount Cecil, "is but one step forward - a very large one, no doubt - in the evolution of international relations which has been in progress for centuries." It is a development of international organization of the past. (1) The concept of international organization has varied greatly with the centuries, but from the first itpresupposed as necessary a number of independent states. State organization was needed in order that there might be interstate or international organization. This organizationcomes about "when the idea of the state as distinct from a family or clan becomes the determining factor in the life of the community." (2)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation of plot yields of one period with those of another
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Soil heterogeneity is probably the greatest obstacle in the way of the correct interpratation of experimental data. Whether the experiment deal with the testing of varieties, of fertilizers or of rotations, soil heterogeneity is always a confusing factor. Of those experimental fields which have been investigated, practically all were found to be sufficiently non uniform as to affect seriously the tests conducted on them. This fact emphasizes the point that greater care must be taken in all agronomic work and that there should be a more extensive use of statistical methods in analysing data if correct conclusions are to be reached in agronomic problems. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Mobility and Boy Behaviour
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is only within recent times that any study of boy behaviour from the point of view of its purely social origin has been made. The boy has been studied merely as an individual and little if any emphasis has been given to those many interesting influences which constantly tend to mold his life and develop his character. But we are becoming conscious of the multiplicity of those influences which constantly play on the individual, and what is more significant, we are beginning to recognize the importance of these influences upon intimate behaviour traits. By a concentration of thought upon the environment of the individual boy we thus find many reasons for the "why" and "how" of his actions. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Sociology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Pernicious anaemia
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The clinical condition known under the various names of Addison's, Biermer's, or pernicious, anaemia was first recognised and described as a clinical entity by Dr. Addison of London in 1849. In 1871 it was independently described on the Continent by Professor Biermer of Zurich, who added very little to Addison's account of the disease (Hurst 1) except to draw attention to the frequency of retinal haemorrhages. Since that time the disease has usually been termed Biermer's anaemia in Germany and Switzerland, while in England it, hasbeen known as pernicious, or primary, idiopathic anaemia. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Molecular attraction
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Progress of science for more than a century has been associated with the development of two concepts, that of force and that of matter. One of the most important discoveries which man made in his study of the universe was that the attractive force between bodies was proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. This same law of attraction was found later to govern the foroes between electrically charged particles and the forces between magnetic poles. The hypothesis that matter is discontinuous has been very successful in explaining the phenomena occurring in the transformations of matter. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Montreal Young Men's Christian Association as areligious and social organization
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: 1. Conditions an4 motives that led to the organization of the Montreal Young Men's Christian Association. The Montreal Young Men's Christian Association, the first on the American Continent, was formed as the result of two meetings of young men from the various evangelical churches of the City, held on December 19th and December 25th, 1851, in the school room of St. Helen Street Baptist Church, "to discuss the practicability of the scheme." At the second of these meetings the actual organization took place, and the following constitution was adopted [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The relation of plot yields of one period with those of another
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Soil heterogeneity is probably the greatest obstacle in the way of the correct interpretation of experimental data. Whether the experiment .deal with the testing of varieties, of fertilizers or of rotations, soil heterogeneity is always a confusing factor. Of those experimental fields which have been investigated, practically, all were found to be sufficiently non uniform as to affect seriously the tests conducted on them. This fact emphasizes the point that greater care must be taken in all agronomic work and that there should be a more extensive use of statistical methods in analysing data if correct conclusions are to be reached in agronomic problems. How often wrong conclusions may have been arrived at, it is impossible to say. In an effort to overcome the influence of soil heterogeneity, various methods of using check plots and replications have been tried out but complete efficiency has never been claimed for any of them. [â€¦]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agriculture

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Application of methods of X-ray crystal analysis to a problem in organic chemistry: effect on the X-ray diffraction pattern of stretching metastyrene, as compared with the effect obtained on stretching rubber
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The essential features of the enormous elasticity exhibited by many colloid systems have not as yet been determined. The stress-strain relationships, the relation between the volume of the colloid and its lengtn (Poissont-s Ratior), the exothermic character of stretching, the phenomenon of elastic after effect (i.e. slow contraction of the released colloid) and the effect of the rate of extension and the temperature of extension on the elasticity of the colloid have heen investigated for some substances but it is not known whether the effects, observed with any one colloid are general or whether they are peculiar to that specific system. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics &Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The colon count as a substitute for the numerical count in the examination of a city milk supply
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: From primeval times mankind has applied heat to food in order to make it more palatable and digestible, but only during the last century and a half has the preservation of food byheat been the definite object. In 1748 Needham, in support of his theory of spontaneous generation, heated putrefiable substances in well-corked flasks, Within a few days his flaskswere peopled with micro-organisms. This, to Needham, wae proof that his theory of spontaneous generation was tenable. Spallanzai, however, in 1765, boiled meat extract for one hour and a half in hermetically sealed flasks and observed that no decomposition of the extract occurred there after. In 1782 Scheele advised the application of this principle to the preservation of vinegar. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Bacteriology

rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Spencer Walpole in beginning his life of Lord Russell says that it is the common practice of biographers to anticipate the story of their hero's life by tracing the achievements ofhis immediate anoestors; and this custom which is perhaps justified by the increasing attention which thoughtful men are paying to the modern doctrine o~ heredity may at first sight seem peculiarly applicable to the present memoir, for if the qualities of a man be really derived from his forefathers. the eminence of Lord John Rusee1l may be traced to circumstances antecedent to his birth. [...]

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Experimental anaemia
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The experiments described in this Thesis arose out of work begun in collaboration with Professor John Tait in which particles of quartz were injected into the circulating blood of rabbits in connection with a study of platelets and of blood coagulation. During the course of these experiments the writer found that nucleated red cells appear in the circulation as a result of injection. Since quartz is practically insoluble the writer began to investigate the effect of particulate matter in general upon the red cell content of the blood, particularly in relation to the haemolyto-poietic function of the reticuloendothelial system. Certain observations have also been made upon the reactions of leucocytes toward single and repeated doses of particles. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The application of the Piezo-electric effect to themeasurement of pressures in internal combustion engines
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is the purpose of this paper to consider the measurement of pressures in internal combustion engines by piezo-electric means, and to advise of the results achieved to date by the author as well as the further developments which have suggested themselves. A brief description of mechanical indicators will not be amiss. It is evident that any moving pistondevices actuating systems of levers would be of little use at the high speeds at which the present-day gas engine is run, chiefly because of the large inertia effects of thesystem. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Mathematics & Physics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Separation and identification of the isomeric ethylidene glycerols
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The importance of the cyclic acetal and ketal glycerols has long attracted the interest of investigators in the field or carbohydrate chemisty. Such workers as Tollens 1,Fischer 2, Karrer 3, Irvine 4 and more- recently Hibbert 5 and his pupils have studied or used this class of compounds in their efforts to explain, by analogy, certain features of the chemical behaviour of the more complex polysaccharides. It is remarkable, therefore, that up to the, present time, the molecular structure of one of the simplest glycerol acetals, namely, ethylidene glycerol has remained undetermined, its formula being given as either, or both, of the two possible isomeric forms. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Valve oscillator design and characteristics
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In connection with the development of apparatus tor the new Communioation Laboratory, the author undertook to investigate the possibility of using a Thermionic Valve Oscillator as a source of high frequency current for experimental work. The object of the investigation was to be a determination of the Frequency Stability and Wave Form of the Output, obtainable. It developed, however, that no method of oscillator design of proven accuracy for low power oscil1ators was available and hence the problem or Frequency Stability and Output Wave Form was deferred until the problem of circuit design could be looked into. This involved a thorough study of the factors entering into the design of a Valve Oscillator and also of the methods used by other investigators. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The 'Lemieux' Act and the Privy Council decision of 1925
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The day of laissez-faire is past. The march of events has brought about the direct necessity of government intervention. Especially is this true in the case of industrial disputes.These are times of organization, amalgamation and concentration. No more does the employer treat with his few help in free and unrestricted fashion, or the benevolent factory owner regard his workmen as his proteges. Those days are gone. Whereas a hundred years ago an industry was a large one if backed with several hundred thousand dollars, to-day there are corporations with a capital of over a billion dollars. With their phenomenal growth, has come the realization of the greater efficiency of association, and amalgamations have gone on apace. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: British naval obligations to France involved in the entente of 1904
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: It is frequent1y stated that on the eve of the Great War. England suddenly awoke to find herself bound by a virtual allianoe to support France in active warfare. In apite of the tact that no signed agreement to this eftect is to be found, it is maintained that the intimacy with which French and British Naval Staffs had discussed and arranged plans for possible co-operation during the previous nine year, had created such an atmosphere of expectancy and dependency on the part of Franoe, that were Great Britain to deny this support, now that the contingenoy against which they had been providing threatened, she would be disgraoed in the sight ot the world and her prestige consequently impaired. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Great Britain -- Foreign relations -- France

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The Stark effect for silver in the visible andultra-violet regions
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Considerable work has been done on the Stark effect for gases, notably hydrogen and helium, but muoh less is known regarding the Stark effect for metals. The application of such a study to metallic spectra is particularly important and instructive since by its aid much light may be thrown on the series relationships of a particular metal. Moreover, in the electric fields which obtain in 10 Surdo discharge phenomena appear whioh are difficult or even impossible to obtain elsewhere. For example, certain spectral lines only appear in very intense fields whereas others are brought out by moderate field intensit1es, disappearing again where the field becomes high. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physics
